title: Winter-Inspired Cocktails by Régime des Fleurs, Arley Marks, Bar Stella
text: 4 Winter-Inspired Cocktails to Make Tonight and All Winter Long February 3, 2017 11:48 PM by Alexandra Malmed Lillies of Forgiveness Photo: Courtesy of Arley Marks Winter evokes a gradation of mental images: blankets of snow over tree branches and piles of firewood, early sunsets and skies of glowing orange, evenings spent indoors in the company of loved ones. The season also calls for cocktails. But then again, which seasons don’t? Perfumers Alia Raza and Ezra Woods, the perfumers behind the Los Angeles–based perfumery Régime des Fleurs and renowned cocktalier Arley Marks and Michael Blum, the head bartender of L.A.’s Bar Stella had those images in mind when they formulated their concoctions. Here are four cocktails meant to evoke the spirit of winter through scent, taste, and appearance. Like the fragrances that Raza and Woods create by hand, the following cocktails are comprised of unique ingredients and inspired by history, culture, architecture, and environmental elements—and sure to give you that hygge , even if you live in the type of place where winter is just a state of mind. Snow Blanketing Flora: Winter Season Bar Stella’s Michael Blum created this drink, which should be served in a stemmed glass like a coupe or Nick & Nora. It requires no garnish, but can be accented with a cherry or slice of dried lemon. Ingredients 2 oz. Barr Hill honey gin1 oz. lemon juice1/4 oz. Liquid Alchemist orgeat1/4 oz. Luxardo maraschino liqueur1 barspoon Dijon blue curaçao Instructions Spray the inside of the glass with absinthe, then sugar the external rim of the glass. Pour ingredients into a cocktail shaker. Shake and strain into the glass. 5pm Sunsets: Lilies of Forgiveness Arley Marks, who worked with Régime des Fleurs to create its spritz for Dimes and recently opened the bar Honey ’s in Brooklyn, named Lilies of Forgiveness after a recent art exhibition that was organized by the perfumers. Ingredients 1 1/2 oz. Yola Mezcal1/2 oz. Enlightenment Wines “Dagger,” cherry hemlock mead1 ounce Uncouth Vermouth, raspberry leaf1/2 oz. fresh, strained lime juice1/2 oz. raw wildflower honey syrup1/2 oz. aqua faba (the protein-rich liquid from a can of garbanzo beans) Instructions To make honey syrup: Stir 1/2 cup raw wildflower honey into 1/2 cup warm water until dissolved, let cool before use. Shake ingredients well in a cocktail shaker with an abundance of ice, then fine-strain into a wine glass. Garnish with flowering herbs, a sprinkle of black salt, and three dashes of Peychauds bitters. Optional: Finish with a spritz of Timelapse edible perfume by Régime des Fleurs . Bright Winter Light: The Kotatsu Inspired by the St-Rita at The Shed in Santa Fe, The Kotatsu takes its name from the Japanese table frame and tradition of draping a blanket between the surface of a table and a heater. Ingredients 1 oz. fresh lime juice1 oz. St. GermainOrange blossom bitters or water, atomizedSalt Instructions In a cocktail shaker, mix the tequila, lime, and St. Germain. Shake and strain into a rocks glass of ice, with a salted rim. Using an atomizer, spray the top with orange blossom bitters or water. Garnish with a slice of dried lime or an orange blossom. Nighttime Indoors: The Aquarius A twist on the classic drink The Penicillin, The Aquarius is simple but intense and, according to some, the perfect drink. Ingredients 3/4 oz. fresh lemon juice3/4 oz. honey-ginger syrup (honey, ginger, and hot water, brought to a boil and chilled overnight)1 1/2 oz. Macallan Scotch2 oz. Jameson, Redbreast, or Japanese Whiskey (made from barley) Instructions Combine whiskey, scotch, lemon juice, and syrup in a cocktail shaker filled with ice; shake vigorously and strain into a rocks glass with one large ice cube.
